entries.title: Functional Programming
entries.description: A programming paradigm where programs are constructed by applying and composing functions.

entries.title: Immutable
entries.description: An immutable object is an object whose state cannot be modified after it is created. They are inherently thread-safe and are simpler to understand and reason about, plus offer higher security than mutable objects.

entries.title: Object Oriented
entries.description: A programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which can contain data and code: data in the form of fields (often known as attributes or properties), and code in the form of methods.

entries.title: Composable
entries.description: A system design principle that deals with the inter-relationships of components. A highly composable system provides components that can be selected and assembled in various combinations to satisfy specific user requirements.

entries.title: Orthogonal
entries.description: Having a small set of composable primitive operations without surprising cross-linkages.

entries.title: Service-Oriented/Componentized
entries.description: We prefer separating functional domains into independent components (and in many cases as independently deployable services)

timeline.description: We should avoid creating new monoliths where all data is in a single schema and the business logic and UI/API layer is all coupled together.
For moving fast and getting to market, we started by creating a single monolith application

entries.title: monolithic
entries.description: A single unified software application which is self-contained and independent from other applications, but typically lacks flexibility

entries.title: Cooperative Concurrency
entries.description: In order to run multiple applications concurrently, processes voluntarily yield control periodically or when idle or logically blocked.

timeline.description: For internal APIs, we prefer to use GraphQL. For external APIs, see JSON APIs.

entries.title: REST APIs
entries.description: REST is an acronym for REpresentational State Transfer and an architectural style for distributed hypermedia systems.

entries.title: JSON APIs
entries.description: Preferred for external facing APIs. For internal only APIs, we prefer to use GraphQL.

entries.title: GraphQL
entries.description: GraphQL is a query language for APIs and a runtime for fulfilling those queries with your existing data. GraphQL provides a complete and understandable description of the data in your API and gives clients the power to ask for exactly what they need and nothing more.

entries.title: Design By Contract
entries.description: An approach for designing software that requires defining formal, precise and verifiable interface specifications for software components.

entries.title: TDD
entries.description: Test Driven Development: a software development process which emphasizes iterative development, starting with a failing test, to reduce time spent chasing bugs and ensure full test coverage at little cost to development speed.

entries.title: Kubernetes
entries.description: Kubernetes is an open-source platform designed to automate deploying, scaling, and operating application containers

timeline.description: We are using Strimzi, ECK operator for Elasticsearch, Prometheus Operator and open to other operators to help with k8s management

entries.title: Grafana
entries.description: Data visualization tool for our metrics

entries.title: Vault
entries.description: A secure secret storage server

entries.title: Consul
entries.description: A distributed service discovery and configuration tool

timeline.description: AWS AppRunner is now being used in production: Recording Proxy Service

entries.title: AWS AppRunner
entries.description: AWS AppRunner is a fully managed service that makes it easy to deploy containerized web applications and APIs without any prior infrastructure or container experience

timeline.description: AWS DocumentDB is now being used in production: Recording Proxy Service (https://invoca.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DEV/pages/59636678734/Call+Recording+Proxy)

entries.title: AWS DocumentDB
entries.description: Amazon DocumentDB (with MongoDB compatibility) is a fully managed, scalable, highly durable, and highly available document database service that offers high performance, high availability, and security. Used by Recording Proxy Service (https://invoca.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DEV/pages/59636678734/Call+Recording+Proxy)

timeline.description: Put on hold in favor of AWS Application Load Balancers (ALB)

entries.title: AWS ELBs
entries.description: From AWS site: "Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) automatically distributes incoming application traffic across multiple targets and virtual appliances in one or more Availability Zones (AZs)"

entries.title: AWS ALBs
entries.description: From AWS site: "Ideal for advanced load balancing of HTTP and HTTPS traffic, Application Load Balancer provides advanced request routing targeted at delivery of modern application architectures, including microservices and container-based applications."

entries.title: Kamailio
entries.description: Open Source SIP Server for load balancing and more

timeline.description: Used for Ingress in places, but no new usage in some time.

entries.title: Nginx
entries.description: A web server that can also be used as a reverse proxy or load balancer

entries.title: Logstash
entries.description: An open source server-side data processing pipeline

entries.title: Kibana
entries.description: Data visualization dashboard software for Elasticsearch

timeline.description: Deprecated in favor of Prometheus and PromQL

entries.title: Graphite
entries.description: Collects, stores, and displays time-series data in real time.

timeline.description: Deprecated in favor of Prometheus and Prometheus exporters

entries.title: Prometheus
entries.description: Open-source monitoring solution

timeline.description: Deprecated in favor of kubernetes

entries.title: Chef
entries.description: A configuration management tool and automates how infrastructure is configured, deployed, and managed across networks

entries.title: Jsonnet
entries.description: A domain specific configuration language from Google

entries.title: Tanka
entries.description: Configuration utility for Kubernetes clusters powered by Jsonnet

entries.title: Ruby
entries.description: An interpreted, high-level, dynamically typed programming language

entries.title: Python
entries.description: A high-level, dynamically typed programming language popular for use in data science

entries.title: JavaScript
entries.description: A dynamically typed programming language that is one of the core technologies of the World Wide Web

timeline.description: Being used as a wrapper of Whisper to power our in-house Speech to Text transcription service

entries.title: Go
entries.description: A statically typed, compiled high-level programming language designed at Google

timeline.description: Prefer Rust or Go over Elixir

entries.title: Elixir
entries.description: A functional, concurrent, high-level programming language that runs on the Erlang VM

timeline.description: Used in the DT Platform, not used in the Invoca Platform

entries.title: PHP
entries.description: General-purpose scripting language geared towards web development

timeline.description: Used in production by PNAPI Bulk Proxy (https://invoca.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DEV/pages/59743568188/PNAPI+Bulk+Proxy+Service+Rust)

entries.title: Rust
entries.description: A general-purpose programming language that emphasizes performance, type safety, and concurrency. It enforces memory safety, meaning that all references point to valid memory, without requiring the use of automated memory management techniques such as garbage collection.

timeline.description: Used by data science team, Whisper core for transcription service, extensions to some low level systems like Freeswitch

entries.title: C++
entries.description: A general-purpose programming language that is object-oriented and has facilities for low-level memory manipulation. Designed with embedded, resource-constrained software and large systems in mind.

timeline.description: Used by our main web application and additional smaller services

entries.title: Ruby on Rails
entries.description: A server-side web application framework written in Ruby

timeline.description: Use for lightweight Ruby services that don't need Rails. Works great with Falcon.

entries.title: Sinatra
entries.description: Open source web application framework written in Ruby and based on Rack

timeline.description: Supplanted by Sinatra + Async + Falcon.
Supplanted by Async.
Should not be used on its own. If doing concurrent programming, use with EM::Synchrony

entries.title: Event Machine
entries.description: An event-driven I/O and lightweight concurrency library for Ruby

timeline.description: Supplanted by Async

entries.title: Event Machine + Synchrony
entries.description: Collection of convenience classes and primitives to help untangle evented code, plus a number of patched EM clients to make them Fiber aware

timeline.description: Works out-of-the-box with Ruby 3. Actively supported, unlike Synchrony (which it supplants).

entries.title: Async
entries.description: A composable asynchronous I/O framework for Ruby based on io-event and timers

timeline.description: Node is now being used in production: Recording Proxy Service

entries.title: NodeJS
entries.description: Node.js is also known for its event-driven non-blocking I/O model, which allows it to handle a large number of concurrent connections efficiently

timeline.description: TypeScript is used in production on the backend (Recording Proxy Service) and the default for Titan app development
TypeScript is now being used to develop the Recording Proxy Service

entries.title: TypeScript
entries.description: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds optional static typing.

entries.title: Sidekiq
entries.description: An open source background job framework written in Ruby

timeline.description: Supported for fast iteration in a Rails service if wrapped by ActiveJob, and eventually migrate to something heavier like Sidekiq if scale requires

entries.title: DelayedJob
entries.description: A simple interface for marshaling a Ruby method call into a database row so that it can be invoked later.

timeline.description: Solid Queue is used in production with the Contact Center Agents service. It simplified the architecture by having a single DB for application and queuing

entries.title: Solid Queue
entries.description: Solid Queue is a DB-based queuing backend for Active Job, designed with simplicity and performance in mind.

entries.title: Unicorn
entries.description: A pre-forking Ruby web server

timeline.description: Use instead of Unicorn or Puma.

entries.title: Falcon
entries.description: A multi-process, multi-fiber rack-compatible HTTP server built on top of async

timeline.description: Supplanted by rspec.

entries.title: MiniTest
entries.description: Small unit testing framework for Ruby

timeline.description: Mocking and stubbing library. Deprecated in favor of rspec-mocks.

entries.title: RR
entries.description: A test double framework for Ruby

timeline.description: No longer maintained by the community. Use headless Chrome or other modern alternatives

entries.title: PhantomJS
entries.description: A discontinued headless browser used for automating web page interaction

timeline.description: We now deploy via setting kubernetes images

entries.title: Capistrano
entries.description: A tool written in Ruby for deploying applications using deployment scripts

entries.title: MySQL
entries.description: Open-source relational database management system (RDMS)

timeline.description: We currently use MySQL due to in house expertise and tooling that has been built up

entries.title: PostgreSQL
entries.description: Open-source relational database management system (RDMS)

entries.title: ElasticSearch
entries.description: A distributed full-text search engine with an HTTP web interface and schema-free JSON documents

entries.title: Kafka
entries.description: A distributed event store and stream-processing platform

timeline.description: InvocaKafka is the preferred wrapper around Racecar (which is a wrapper around ruby-kafka)

entries.title: Kafka Racecar
entries.description: Kafka consumer framework written in Ruby

entries.title: Redis
entries.description: Open-source in-memory storage, used as a distributed, in-memory key–value database, cache and message broker

timeline.description: Redis is the preferred solution for a shared cache for use in web services

entries.title: Memcache
entries.description: A shared memory cache used by the web platform and integrated into rails

entries.title: AWS ElastiCache
entries.description: An in-memory cache in the AWS cloud, compatible with both Redis and Memcached

entries.title: AWS S3
entries.description: Simple Storage Service (S3) is an object storage service offering scalability, data availability, security, and performance

timeline.description: DT Platform used it for DNI service (SourceTrak), no Invoca uses in production

entries.title: AWS Dynamo
entries.description: A fully managed, serverless, key-value NoSQL database designed to run high-performance applications at any scale

timeline.description: Was used for holding Call conversion records that hit our API ahead of the call being imported, now converted to Kafka + Sidekiq. Consider ElasticSearch or AWS Dynamo.

entries.title: MongoDB
entries.description: A cross-platform, document-oriented NoSQL database

timeline.description: Was evaluated for Conversation Reporting warehouse - selected ElasticSearch instead

entries.title: Redshift
entries.description: Cloud data warehousing solution by AWS

entries.title: RabbitMQ
entries.description: BunnyBus is the Invoca library built on top of RabbitMQ

timeline.description: Using Databricks in production as a replacement for the data science team's JuyperHub infrastructure and notebooks, and to power Signal AI Studio

entries.title: DataBricks
entries.description: A Cloud-based Data Engineering tool that is used to process/transform/explore large quantities of data

entries.title: Kops
entries.description: Kubernetes Cluster Management

entries.title: Docker Desktop
entries.description: Container Runtime for Local Development
